definition: an aspect marker used in verb forms to indicate either a benefactive action (= indirect object) or an experiential action, (see Les.17E)
an enclitic affixed to vocatives and imperatives, used especially when calling children or when calling from a distance
postposition from, than (in comparisons); since, after (affixed to participial forms, Les. 33)
the possessive marker affixed to nouns or pronouns (Les. 2,38)
an aspect marker used in verb forms to indicate a durative action (Les. 17)

to sneeze, (there is a belief that sneezing on the part of a sick person who does not have a cold can be a sign or omen that he will recover from his sickness, therefore in a prayer achuḱ kenoḱkâć/achuḱ kenkâć would mean 'may he recover'
verbal affix in the meanwhile (Les. 27).
verbal affix in the meanwhile (also antaa) (Les.27)
a verbal affix, to do the action mentioned before -atú and then leave. (Les. 27).
a verbal affix, to divide something into two approximately equal parts; with words such as buṭa or koto in prayers, to divide off forming new stalks or branches.
isn't it? isn't he? etc. (an enclitic following the word or words to which it refers; often used with irony)
alternate form of -ka, the optative mood marker (Les. 34)
affixed to participial forms to indicate an action preceding another action (te is more commonly used for this and -et́ is also sometimes used)
an enclitic usually implying contrast (same as the enclitic-do in meaning) (often following ge in the form-geda. When used without-ge the vowel is often lengthened -da

subwords.sub_definition: da (as above) + the enclitic-ga (connoting respect) (when-ga is used the tendency is to use-da rather than -do

definition: a frequently used enclitic, usually implying some contrast do (1) an exclamation inviting someone to do something along with the speaker (also dola. When addressing one person the form dolan is usually used, when addressing two or more the form dolabu)

subwords.sub_definition: let me (do+ka+ń) urging oneself to do something
having repeated invited someone to join on in some action

an exclamation meaning literally 'come on then' but with the meaning 'come and see whether or not... (spoken by one who wants to show others who are sceptical that he can do or has done something; the following verb is often preceded by ka)

definition: affixed to participial forms to indicate an action having been done (same as -te or -chi, Les. 34)
an enclitic indicating respect (used more toward Chakradharpur and the North of the Ho country).

an enclitic emphasizing the word to which it is affixed; the use of a root+ge+a verb-form of the same root is used with the mean- ing 'keep on' (doing the action ex- pressed in the root), e.g. jom ge jomè me ká nogot́ reó, keep on eating even if it is not tasty'.
an enclitic affixed to a word for emphasis.
an enclitic added to words in songs merely to fill out the sound.

—verbal affix. This has 2 usages - a) taking a direct object it means to cause, make, e.g. sen-ichikom, ‘make them go’, b) taking an -a aspect marker it means to allow, permit, e.g. sen-ichiakom, ‘let them go’
verbal affix - to cause (also -ichi, Les. 27)

verbal affix - to one’s advantage (Les. 27). This is a refl. usage and does not take an . obj. marker even if an obj. is expressed,e.g. Poesa nam-joṅ me, ‘get some money for yourself’. In the past tense instead of this -jom construction, an -an construction is used (past refl, of -a aspect, Les. 17E) e.g. Poesań namana, ‘I got money for myself’)

the bound form of the 3rd pers. pl. personal pronoun, ‘they’ ‘them’; affixed to a noun or pronoun it forms the pl. number. (in a few expressions -ko is used of one person to show respect, e.g. héyarko, ‘father-in-law’ said by his daughter-in-law); in verb forms it indicates a pl. animate sub. and/or obj. A -ko marker is often added to a noun to include other like objects and to verbs to include other lke actions (Les. 37). In some cases -ko or -kote affixed to a word connoting time means approximately, e.g. gapakote, ‘about tomorrow’, ‘one of these days’

subwords.sub_definition: an exclamation of wonder or surprise

definition: an enclitic, much like do, often implying some contrast (in expression Jeṭe ma Jargi , it means Jeṭe reó Jargi reó , ‘rain or shine’
a verbal affix meaning ‘before’ (also maat́ ) (Les. 27)
verbal affix - before (Les. 27)
an enclitic same as -ma, q.v.
an enclitic, same as -ma, q.v.
an enclitic affixed to words like mar, ate, etc, when one woman is addressing another woman
an enclitic affixed to words in songs in order to fill out the rhythm

(affixed to a word) and, also; even (esp. with negatives, e.g. miat́ ó banoḱa, 'there isn't even one'); sometimes a root + ó + a full verb form of the same root is used, e.g. tam ó ko tam ket́ića, 'and besides that they also will beat him'; this construction is sometimes used to indicate that both of two actions occured, e.g. saṕ ókô saṕ ket́ića annḍoḱ tam ókô tam ket́ića, 'they both caught and beat him.'

the voice marker for the passive voice in the simple (without aspect markers) future and related tenses (Les. 8). Besides having a strictly passive usage this often has an inchoative usage indicating coming into some state and can often be translated by 'become' (Les. 8 and 26, section 2b); oḱge often has an adverbial usage, e.g. moć-moćoḱge (= moć-moć + oḱge) - 'beautifully', dir-diroḱgeć duṕ akana, he is sitting with his shoulders thrown back'

affixed to many words means as long as, until (implies some duration of time) as dinoḱ, gáṛioḱ, imitaoḱ, chiminoḱ, e.g. setaḱ aete ayuṕoḱgekô paeṭia, 'they work from morning until evening' (perhaps this usage is a function of the passive tense marker -oḱ)

The reciprocal infix (the reciprocal of any verb can be formed by infixing the reciprocal marker -p- after the first vowel of a verb root and then repeating that vowel after the -p-. If this first vowel is long, it retains its long quality only after the -p- infix (Les. 23); a -p- infix is also used in a few superlatives, e.g. máparaṅ, hupuḍiṅ, jipiliṅ; also a -p- infix is used in a few terms implying relationship, e.g. eperate, 'his wife', hopon, sepeet́ (prob. from sēt́ as in hon sēt́)
an affix indicating an approximate place (-taḱ would indicate an exact place)

an enclitic affixed to a word (which word is then repeated) for purposes of emphasis, e.g. by someone crying out to sell wares, e.g. gotomkorē gotom!, 'ghee for sale!' (used in stories, in ordinary usage -hai is used in this way)

a possessive form taking endings ń (1st sg.), m (2nd sg.), e (3rd sg.), laṅ (1st incl. dl.), etc. usually affixed to the word possessed, e.g. hontań, 'my child', but sometimes put before it, e.g. Ó tań hon, 'oh! my child'; these forms can also be affixed to verb forms, e.g. honko baṅkoa-takin, the two of them have no children'; also these forms are used to translate 'this thing of mine', ';this thing of yours', etc. (anim. or inanim.) e.g. mar tam ideme, come on now, take yours (sg.)' (Les. 38)

verbal affix always followed by taṕ (quickly) with the combination meaning 'very quickly', in a flash', 'in an instant' (more emphatic than -taṕ alone), e.g. sadomkoko har tór taṕ ket́koa, They drove off the horses in a flash
verbal affix, 'again', 'back' (Les. 27).
verbal affix, utterly (Les. 27).
same as-utar, -utterly (Les. 27).
a mouth, beak; the mouth of a vessel.

subwords.sub_definition: to yawn (Les. 26)
a long beak, e.g. of stork.

a spell caused by flattery, mantras or other spoken words (compare nojor a spell cast by the evil eye); to speak ill of others; to so cast a spell on someone (thereby causing harm to him or to something belonging to him, e.g. his cultivation).
a spirit who inflicts harm through flattery, mantras or other spoken words.
a jungle scrub much used as medicine for fever and stomach trouble, probably Andrographis paniculata, Nees, Acanthaceae B 104/3, H.104/31/1
sores around the mouth (considered a sign that a person is recovering from sickness). Of these sores people sometimes say 'Siṅgbonga atar ket́ića' (see atar)
word of mouth, conversation
word of mouth, conversation
chin (also merely Kiya)
the part of the face surrounding the mouth, esp. the corners of the mouth.
lips
lips
the front part of the mouth, including lips
sometimes used in jest for marchi, a chilli
a word, a few words (e.g. in the expression mit́ Ah reó kajièm, 'say at least something'); (when followed by a noun) a mouthful, e.g. mit́ Ah jilu, a mouthful of meat.
to blurt out something esp. in displeasure or anger rendering someone else speechless. (This seems to be used only with the verbal affix tab, 'quickly'

definition: a cry made by a bear when in pain; of a bear, to make such a cry

var. of aagu. to lower; refl. to get down, descend; to put down as an offering an egg or eggshell or turmeric to propitiate some spirit, destination. e.g. a nage Bonga; of chickens, to enter into a field (usually over an embankment, and hence down). As a verbal affix adu is usually translated by the word 'down' e.g. hurla-aadu to throw down.
to lower (also aadu, q.v.).
a herb, an edible leaf; pass. or refl. verb, of an edible leaf, to develop.

subwords.sub_definition: any hill on which herbs are found or are found in abundance. There is an Aaḱ Buru village
a term sometimes used in short for mani (Aaḱ) jaṅ, q.v.
vegetables
a collective noun for edible herbs and mushrooms which can be gotten from the jungles; a term used when referring to famine food.

definition: to let free, release; to pardon; to let go of the hand one is holding when dancing in order to make room for someone else in the line; with Bohḱ to let down one's hair; of one herding cattle, goats, etc. to let them roam (e.g. into another's field); to release a fighting cock for a fight.

subwords.sub_definition: to release and let enter (e.g. cattle into someone's field)
to set free, release; (with Urić expressed or understood as obj.) to let cattle roam free without cow-herder (as is done in summer).
seasons when the cattle are allowed to roam freely.
fish which have been released in some tank, etc. (i.e. big fish such as Rui, Katala, Boa which are bought for this purpose).

definition: marriage; to marry; with Oaḱ, 'house' as object, to bless a newly made house; various anagu same meaning as forms of marriage among the Hos are as follows, 1) arranged marriages, called Goṅ Aandi, Kiriṅ Aandi, or Bapala Aandi. This is normally held at the house of the boy. A marriage held at the girl's house or officiated over by a Brahmin would be called Diku Aandi, 2) elopement by mutual consent of the couple, usually referred to as Kepea, 3) holding back a girl visiting a village to be the wife of a man of the village, referred to as sasaṅ-uraa, 4) taking a girl from e.g. a feast or a market without her previous consent, referred to as Oꝑor-Tipić.

subwords.sub_definition: rice beer prepared for a marriage.
any Kanḍa Chaṭu (a type of earthen pot) in which rice beer is put for a marriage.
rice beer prepared for a marriage in a Kanḍa Chaṭu

definition: three each
yoke; to yoke; refl. to attach oneself to the yoke (instead of cattle, e.g. as is done on the occasion of bringing a stone to be put on the grave of a dead person).

subwords.sub_definition: the rope used to tie to the yoke (if seen in a dream it represents a snake)
certain stars forming a yoke design, probably the belt of the Orion constellation, and perhaps part of the sword of the same constellation.yt

a yoke with animals unevenly matched, e.g. one bigger than the other; usage ãar kacha tat́kinać 'he yoked together two unevenly matched bullocks'; figur. refl. (ãar-kachan) to be united in some endeavour with someone with whom you are not well matched
plough cattle
a team of ploughing cattle

definition: a weakness in the waist; of the waist, to be afflicted by weakness.
of a hen, to sit on eggs; to shelter her chickens under her wings; of a woman, to hold her child near her (when sleeping, etc.). a̱+burum?

subwords.sub_definition: the star sitting on the 'dove eggs' (Putam Jarom Ipil kin ), probably the first magnitude star Aldebaran in the constellation Taurus.

definition: you two
we three or more, inclusive of the person or persons addressed.
to wash the hands or feet
an exclamation - good, all right (from the Hindi accha.)
to sow paddy in watery mud. (For this sometimes the paddy seeds are first kept in water for about 24 hours so that they will begin to sprout)

subwords.sub_definition: paddy sown as given under achaa
the month when the sowing is done in watery mud, usually July
to make a nursery for rice seedlings in watery mud.

definition: sudden, suddenly; by chance; by accident
a plant that looks like the tulsi plant, but gives out a different smell, prob. Ocimum canum, Sims., Labiatae B. 106/17, H. 106/1/3

to transfer grown silkworms from one tree (where they have eaten up all the leaves) to another tree (a + chal, q.v. The prefix a- in front of certain verbs has a causative function. See also àjal, àjom, ànu, àsen, àkariṅ).

subwords.sub_definition: a branch used to transfer silkworms from one tree to another.
same as achal danḍa.

definition: the iron point fixed to the end of a goading stick

subwords.sub_definition: a goad, a stick with a sharp iron point for animals.

definition: alternate form of at́chiã or hat́chiã, q.v.
to employ, to hire or order someone to do some work; refl. to engage oneself in some work, to take up some work.

definition: to sneeze, (there is a belief that sneezing on the part of a sick person who does not have a cold can be a sign or omen that he will recover from his sickness, therefore in a prayer achuḱ kenoḱkâć/achuḱ kenkâć would mean 'may he recover'

subwords.sub_definition: a herb, the leaf of which if held near to the nose causes sneezing, prob. Centipeda venerated. orbicularis, Lour., Compositae, E.M., B.78/13, H.78/38/1

to already know.

definition: the ginger plant, Zingiber officinale, Rosc., Zingiberaceae, B.156/13, H.156/7/3. Its root is used as a spice. This boiled with tea leaves gives a very good medicine against coughs
one half (Hindi)

subwords.sub_definition: a severe headache in one half of the head, such as is caused by sinus headaches.

definition: to collect something due, e.g. taxes
a pitiful condition, e.g. from weakness, hunger
to bring in; as verbal affix in, into (Les. 27) $
the inner room of a house where the cooking is done and where the ancestors are venerated

subwords.sub_definition: to portion off part of a house for the Adiṅ.
midnight (also tala nida)

definition: to make less, to become less, to decrease.
paisa, (the old half pice)

to sneeze, (there is a belief that sneezing on the part of a sick person who does not have a cold can be a sign or omen that he will recover from his sickness, therefore in a prayer achuḱ kenoḱkać/achuḱ kenkać would mean 'may he recover'

subwords.sub_definition: rice husked without being first boiled.
the root of the turmeric plant (Sasaṅ) as it comes out of the ground previous to being dried out

definition: to have no desire to eat (e.g. because one's hunger is sated, or because one is fed up with getting the same thing again and again.)
to make less; to become less, to decrease.
some; some.... others
one of the guru Bongako called upon by Deõas (called by some Akai Bír).
an incense stick (used in a story. These are not normally used by Hos in their rituals).

a promise to one of the greater spirits (Siṅgbonga, Maraṅbonga, Máburu, Nage) to perform a certain sacrifice upon receiving some specified favour (recovery from sickness, good crop). An outward sign of this make less; to promise (Sindur, Adoa Chauli... etc.) is wrapped in a leaf.

subwords.sub_definition: to promise. ceremonially that one will perform a sacrifice on the following day.
to promise before sleeping at night to perform a sacrifice the following day.

definition: a kind of crane (bird), many of which fly very high in formation; probably the Demoiselle Crane, and/or the Common Crane
to bring (also au). As verbal affix this means either to bring or to come down from some former times, e.g. some traditional way of acting.(Les. 27)

subwords.sub_definition: to bring to a destination
to spread by bringing from somewhere else, e.g. some new kind of seed. (For spreading a disease Hos would use jan)
to bring along when ać he, she he coming.

to come bringing.

seven (short form)

definition: an exclamation sometimes used preceding a vocative and sometimes used affixed to a word as given under hai q.v. When affixed this is heard often in terms such as elabu ái, dolabu ái, ocha ái.
seven (long form)
to jump in a forward direction; to jump across, to transgress, e.g. a command (cf. uć to jump up and down)

to jump upon

rice beer and food separately portioned off (cf. kanda) at the time of Bapala or marriage for the older sister of the bride and her friends.
a goat taken from the house of a boy by the family of a girl with whom the boy has run away (also called Chinḍi Merom), This is considered as a peace offering to the older sister of the girl.

a chicken taken as given under Aji Hanhr Merom; a chicken given to the older sister of a bride by the party (OrEra ko) who come to bring the bride to the house of her husband-to-be for the marriage (usually a black hen (Kaluṭi) and a cock are given)
his or her older sister (literally the one who was older sister to...)

a bow

same as Aḱ Bonga.
a bent (like a bow) back; hunched back

dumbfounded, confused.

to be at a loss as to what to do; as adj. with bir (jungle) very thick.

the dancing ground; the arena for a cockfight; to come together for conversation or play.
to be amazed; amazement (Les. 26)

famine (Hindi, ringa is the proper Ho word for this)

noticeably in advanced pregnancy (within a week or so before giving birth, used esp. of animals, e.g. goats, but also sometimes used of women)

moisture (for this jiãa is more common)

a white, intestinal worm (prob. The pin worm or seat worm). E.M. gives 'about 3 inches long, found in man, fowl and cattle, esp. in buffaloes'. (For the large intestinal round worm Hos use lendad).
a hill in Orissa named in prayers.
partially ripe, e.g. of a fruit.
for the whole lower part of the plough to enter into the soil as one ploughs (when the field is soft and well soaked, cf. budu-budu).
competition (e.g. in dancing, singing).
a peanut (short form of chinabadam) men.
a dwarf (usually referring to a spirit except in terms such as baram-lekan hō, a dwarf (man) and baram-lekać harakana, 'his growth was stunted' (like that of a dwarf).

an abnormally small egg.

definition: a flying fox.
a long dragnet for catching fish.

a strip of silk-cocoon that has been cut to the proper thickness to tie an arrowhead to the arrow; to tie with such a strip; the leather strips used to span drums; poetic parallel of juḍi, a mate or companion, used in a marriage song; refl. badinn -to strongly commit (tie) oneself to some action (Sometimes the double term badinn tanae, tolenn tanać is used for this).
used in prayers parallel to ladi, or in the jingle ladi- badi with the meaning of ladi, 'to load upon'.
used in prayers parallel to hisa, or to hisa-chenṭa with the meaning 'to harass'.
poetic parallel of piṛi, a field.
a large full beard.
an antelope (E.M. the Sasin or Indian antelope).
a bat, a small flying fox (cf. badara).

definition: the initial thin strip made when making a jaṭi (a palm mat); to prepare such an initial strip.
a share; to give someone his share.

definition: the condition of being under threat of serious (even lethal) harm caused by either a) the witchcraft (bai, banai) of another, or b) by one's having displeased the bagia (q.v.) spirits of the jungle; pass. verb to be in such a condition (a sign of this is sometimes that tiger hair (kula īyal or kula daria) is found in one's rice, or that the colour of one's rice has become reddish).
a garden (also bakai).
see bagra.
a box.

to leave, abandon, relinquish; refl. to dissociate oneself or take oneself away from a person or situation (e.g. a woman leaving her husband or a dasi leaving his work), also in refl. we can say kaji kać bagen tana, 'he doesn't stop talking law).

subwords.sub_definition: to leave behind.
to abandon or desert; to neglect (e.g. a parent not taking proper care of his or her child); refl. to neglect (not care for) oneself; to deny oneself.
to let die through neglect.
besides, e.g. nea bagekete, 'besides this'.

definition: the shade of a person killed by a tiger. The bagia spirits are believed to control the jungle tigers and sometimes inflict them on people. They also make noises to scare people in the jungle.

subwords.sub_definition: same as bagia.

definition: a reddish-brown colour, a mixture of araḱ (reddish brown) and kasae (a deeper reddish brown), sometimes used of the colour of tigers, goats, etc.

of leaves, vegetables, etc., to grow in abundance, big and close to one-another.

sweet-scented oil.
same as Bah Dumbu.

at least (see baet́).

subwords.sub_definition: used in prayers parallel to dili-giti:, q.v.
to pass one's time enjoyably (while away one's time) making a sound as given under baka.

same as bala, used for vocative.
same as balako.

as under bandi sonoroḱ; the guisa fish (so called in jest).

a particle translated by 'is/are not', indicating that there is not an identity, e.g. enić ańaḱ hon do bano, he is not my child' (Les.18); used in phrases indicating one or other (a disjunction), e.g. musiṅg bano musiṅg, 'some day or other', midō bano midō, 'someone or other', jaiḱ bano jaiḱ, 'someone or other', chikanaḱ bano chikanaḱ, 'something or other' okontaḱ bano okontaḱ 'somewhere or other'.

participial form of banoḱa, q.v. (banoḱa minus mood marker -a), occurring esp. in the meaning of 'not having' (something inanimate), e.g. jomeaḱ banoḱ sepeet́ ko, 'young men having no food', asora banoḱ hatu, 'a village in which one has no relatives' (In these cases when the noun following banoḱ is animate, the alternate form banoḱten can be used, e.g. jomeaḱ banoḱten sepeet́ ko).

subwords.sub_definition: a destitute family (house).
same as banoḱ Oaḱ.

definition: it/they (inani- mate) is/are not present or does/ do not exist (Les.18). This can be used in the form banoḱ akana, 'it no longer exists'.

an adjectival form modifying an animate noun and meaning 'not possessing' some inanimate object which is expressed previous to the word banoḱten, e.g. jomeaḱ banoḱten honko, children having no food, ote-hasa banoḱten hōko, 'landless people'. If no object is expressed previous to banoḱten, it would mean 'possessing nothing', 'desti- tute' e.g. banoḱten hōko, 'destitute men'. From the form banoḱten noun forms can be formed, banoḱtiniḱ (sg.), bano-tenking (dl.) and banoḱtenko (pl), e.g. poysa banoḱtenko, 'people without money'.

a rogue elephant fed.

alone, off by itself, e.g. of a solitary tree or house.

definition: a kind of creeper, the tender shoots of which are edible and sometimes eaten by cowherds, etc. (This is much like iiḱ towar and is prob. Vitis tomentosa, Heyne., Ampelidaceae, H.47/1/9, B.47/9).
to boil water.

subwords.sub_definition: about 4-5 P.M. when water is put on the fire for the evening meal.
to sterilize by boiling; to boil and let cool off. Bine.
water which has been in the Chaṭu from the previous day.
rice beer which has been strained the previous day.
water in which rice was cooked the previous day.
for something, e.g. cooked rice or curry, to be exceedingly stale to the point of almost rotting.

cooked rice which has been kept overnight without putting water into it, and hence which has developed a smell (cooked rice into which water has been put is referred to as daḱ Manḍi even when taken the next day which is usually the case).
something held over for two days (may be used of rice beer, also of the day after basi of the mage feast, also called mage moroć or har mage).

definition: left over from the previous day; the day after the main day of any feast.
a fish hook; to fish with a line and hook.

subwords.sub_definition: a fishing rod.
a fishing line.

definition: to take something to eat about basiam singi time; pass. to become this time (used in terms basiamakana, 'it has become basiam singi time', or singi doć basiamoḱa, 'The sun will reach basiam singi time').

subwords.sub_definition: about 8 to 10 A.M.
some time about 10A.M. to noon.
about 8-9 A.Μ.
about 9-10 A.M.

definition: baba a variety of small grained rice for lowland fields, very tasty and sweet smelling.
a tree resembling the hesaḱ tree, but having slightly bigger fruit and more wide-spread branches; probably Ficus infectoria, Roxb., Moraceae, B.125/10, H.125/ 8/7 Η.

certainly, by all means; to demand (e.g. of a girl before going for her marriage, to hold on to the feet of a relative until she is given a going-away gift); of a dewa, etc. to put a curse on someone; refl. baden to put a curse on oneself, e.g. goćoḱkań menteć bat́entana, 'She curses herself to die'.

subwords.sub_definition: to insist (in asking, giving, etc).
with great difficulty.
with difficulty (e.g. because of some physical weakness, etc., or because very much against one's wishes).

definition: the cries of many goats or sheep.
rheumatism.

bamboos or harasae jaṭa used to reinforce thatch or to fasten jáyu, on which tiles will be put, more tightly to the seneor (N.B. jayu is used of the thin strips of wood put across the seneor to support the tiles or thatch).
a type of artificial spur (kati) on a cock which has two handles for tying it on very tightly.
a branch or branches of the tiril tree planted on the batauli feast (used on prayers of the batauli feast).
a grasshopper.

subwords.sub_definition: a collective noun for grasshoppers.

definition: a kiln.

subwords.sub_definition: the fire of a kiln.

definition: the Common or Gray Quail Fonte.
to fall over repeatedly (see baṭi).
to starve (scrape for a little bit to eat) (Note saying- menaḱ redo haṭaḱ-haṭaḱ banoḱ redo baṭaḱ-baṭaḱ 'when you have there is abundance (haṭaḱ -winnowing basket) when you do not have you starve).
of a woman, by using undue pressure, flattering, exaggerating and the like, to urge a girl (woman) to elope with a man.

subwords.sub_definition: same as bátaḍa.

definition: thin (of a person); high pitched (of a voice).

subwords.sub_definition: properly thin and tall.

definition: a sacrifice to obtain protection for the paddy when it starts to flower so that insects won't eat it, to obtain proper rain, etc.; the feast for the same; refl. to observe this sacrifice and feast.
sabai grass, used to make ropes for beds, etc. Pollinidium angustifolium, Gramineae, B.139/34, H.139/61/1.

subwords.sub_definition: rope made of bat́chom.

definition: a daily portion of uncooked rice given e.g. to a cowherd (besides this he receives an annual wage of a certain number of baskets of paddy, depending on the number of cattle, sheep, etc.).
a lamp wick; a bright lamp, e.g. electric (see dibri, lalten for the lamps usually used in the homes).

subwords.sub_definition: a lamp-stand Troup.

definition: a small measuring cup (about a half seer).
to overturn, to knock over something standing upright; pass. of something standing, to fall on its side; refl. to turn over, to turn from side to side.

subwords.sub_definition: to overturn causing to go down.
to remove something out of the way by turning it over.
a paddy bundle, the outer ropes (bandi baver) of which are fixed by rolling the bundle along the ground.
to pretend to turn or fall over (refl. form).
to overturn and repeatedly roll over.
(refl. form repeated) roll over (said playfully at the end of a verse by one playing the banam or the flute).
another name for the guri: uru (dung beetle), so called because making a ball of dung, it rolls it over into a hole which it has made.

definition: a word (not translatable in a uniform way) put after a word or phrase to which the main subject is compared, usually unfavorably, indicating that the subject would prefer the action to which batil is attached than that to which it is compared, e.g. achaa do ka rãasaoḱa, kakô her dae yan redo roa batilkô roaèa. 'They do not like to sow in water; if they have not been able to sow, they would rather transplant (they would prefer to transplant); Sometimes used after a noun or pronoun, e.g. ać alom emaića, am batil jomè me, 'Do not give it to him, rather you eat it'.
used in a story-song in the term bēt baṭilo apparently meaning the same as bēṭ dandaḱ, 'a rattan cane' (baṭilo is not a Ho word. Some story songs mix some Oria with the Ho).
a poetic parallel to hiatiṅ, 'to feel pity' (more often cakatiṅ is used for this).
same as batil, q.v.
same as batil, q.v.
rheumatism (also bat).
a long-standing swelling esp. in the foot or leg; elephantiasis; pass. To be thus swollen.

subwords.sub_definition: a badly swollen leg or legs (this term when referred to someone (batua kaṭaanić) would be spoken in ridicule or scorn).

definition: an edible herb, sometimes cultivated and sold in the market; Clenopodium album, L. Clenopodiaceae, B.109/3 H.109/ 1/1.
whitish matter or mould which forms on certain objects (e.g. bakara fruit, paddy stalks, leather) which start to decompose; of mould, to form.
older brother, or older male cousin.

subwords.sub_definition: older brother.
a man's wife's older brother; a woman's husband's older brother.

definition: to be mildly crazy (normally transitory) as a consequence of a serious illness; used as parallel with rum, 'to shake in a trance'.
mildly crazy (syn. of bāra-būru, q.v.); of e.g. a spirit, to make someone mildly crazy Bad.

subwords.sub_definition: a slim black centipede smaller than the sengel marmar and not poisonous, called baura because of the irregular way in which it wriggles along.

definition: of a woman, mildly crazy (see baura); figur. to do something in a foolish or stupid manner.
a rope; to tie with a rope, (a rope seen in a dream could refer to a snake and the threat of a spirit to throw a rope at someone could mean that he would send a snake to bite that person).

subwords.sub_definition: to let down by a rope.
a bow in which the bow string is made of rope instead of a thin strip of bamboo (made for small children to play with).

definition: a narrow strip of plaited palm leaves (these strips are stitched together by means of strong twine into palm mats, jaṭi).
crazy; to make crazy.

subwords.sub_definition: delirious; the confused state of one overwhelmed e.g. with too many pressing works to be done.
a larger type of togo (a variety of civet cat): a smaller variety is called biskal togo).
delirious; speaking nonsense when delirious.
a type of churdu bonga which causes temporary insanity to those whom it.
a servant spirit to rankani juguni and bir juguni.
dull wittted; of e.g. a spirit, to cause someone to become dull-witted; pass. -to become dull-witted.
nonsense.
insane (a generic term, tuta means 'epileptic').

definition: to roam from place to place looking for or asking for something.
an edible creeper found in the jungle, prob. Vitis auriculata, Laws., Ampelidaceae, H.47/1/16, B.47/6., for which Haines gives 'baiang' (this may $.
a castrated male goat; to castrate by cutting (cf. kuṭa).
at least (often used after a verb root followed by a full verb form from that same root).
an advance paid on something; earnest money given to clinch a sale-contract $.
used in prayers parallel with or in conjunction with rogo, 'a contagious disease', prob. same as bed(e), q.v.iataeng.

a loud call made by repeatedly putting the back of the hand to the mouth producing a sound something like bebe-bebe (used when hunting to excite a sail (bison) or to urge one-another on to kill or trap a sail).
spittle; to spit (takes transitive verb forms); to spit upon (beć means to spit out saliva; leleć is used meaning to spit out e.g. a $.

subwords.sub_definition: to spit out saliva.
to spit all over (used in prayers with the parallel käeć-topa with the figur. meaning of 'to show disrespect').
spittle.

definition: quickly, fast (used both independently and as verbal affix).
without (sometimes used with the instrumental affix -te affixed to the noun, e.g. begar paitikote, 'without works'. This is a Sadri term, often heard in Mundari, but rare in Ho).
a kind of shrub or tree, which has thin branches and which if put in a chicken-pen causes chicken lice to leave; Vitex negundo, L., Verbenaceae, B.105/21 H.105/10/2.
unconscious (Hindi, better Ho would be goć-anjed).
used only in the term beja sim, q.v.

subwords.sub_definition: a chicken entrusted by the head of a household to be sacrificed by a diuri and then taken back to be eaten by the members of the household (this is done on the occasion of the Bah feast and also at the time of a borobonji sacrifice) videdorg.

definition: to converse laughingly and light-heartedly, e.g. of young people when dancing.
the Bel tree, Aegle marmelos, Correa., Rutaceae, B. 36/1, H.36/14/1 (see also lowagasiḱ, the same as above, perhaps esp. as found in its wild state).
a round bowl, bigger than a gina.

subwords.sub_definition: a bela with water in it.
a collective noun for vessels used for eating.

definition: European, foreign (in certain contexts, see below).

subwords.sub_definition: a tomato; Lycopersicum esculentum, Mill., Solanaceae, B.97/8, H.97/6/1.
a particular kind of sturdy flat tiles.
a kind of small sturdy dog, perhaps esp. the bulldog.

definition: a pick-axe.
to playfully clown around (e.g. wrestling) with someone. Often used in the recip. bepeleṅ.
a blade (e.g. for shaving).
to be unable to recollect something.
to become alarmed and fearful, e.g. of cattle sensing the approach of jungle animals. Can be used also of men.
a jungle creeper having small white pods which are ground down and used for scrubbing brass plates and such objects.
a bench.
bonga a spirit served by hunters or cock-fighters (also called tuń benḍekar bonga).
to fall with a sweeping (arching) motion, e.g. the branches of vines lopped off, the head of a chicken cut off. berriso.

subwords.sub_definition: the same of a repetitive action e.g. of a Supit́ (hair knot) bobbing up and down.

the brinjal or egg-plant; Solanum melongena, L., Solanaceae, B.97/14 H.97/5/9.

subwords.sub_definition: a tomato.
an egg-plant.

definition: parallel running stripes of alternate color (e.g. as of a junjui, or a striped cloth).
excellent, fine, good looking, e.g. esu bengan kajikote, 'with very fine words'.
same as bengeleć.
coloured with stripes alternately reddish or reddish-brown and a lighter colour, e.g. of the junjui, a small smooth-skinned lizard.
a commercial bank.
a turban; to wear something around the head like a turban.
used parallel to or affixed to chenṭa, q.v., with the same meaning.
a cup-like receptacle for oil.
trade, to trade.

low-lying fields (also called sal).
of a man, to be carried away and eaten by a tiger; of a place, to become very unsafe because of the presence of a tiger.
same as berangi, q.v.
a dragonfly.
very (so used in the Chakradharpur area).

to tear, cut, etc. into small pieces (also beteć-beteć).

unripe; of wood, unseasoned, green; of meat or vegetables, uncooked, raw; of water, unboiled; of the body of a woman after childbirth, still weak and sensitive to pain; of the complexion of a young person, fresh (as in the term esel-berel).

of fruit, still raw and inedible (not yet bada, 'partially ripe').

used as poetical parallel with rog, pain, suffering (perhaps from Hindi 'wedna').

subwords.sub_definition: a rattan cane, made from the beṭ daru (sometimes brought from Assam).

definition: weakness and pain, esp. in the waist but sometimes in the chest or ribs, due esp. to old age (apparently a form of rheumatism).

a day.
a day.
to tear, cut, etc. into small pieces (into shreds).

definition: to startle; to be startled, to start (Les. 26).
to move across water with an undulating motion (e.g. of tiny insects); to deliberately bend the finger up and down.

subwords.sub_definition: same as betoḱ of a continued or repeated action to.
of one drowsy or doz- ing off while sitting, for the head to bob up and down.

judgment, to judge; to pass judgment on (see also sirma bichar).

a passing judgment (sanala -verbal noun of sala, to select.

of the tail e.g. of a cow or a lizard, to be turned somewhat upward.
naughty (also bisiḱ-bina) corrbottom of which are small.
to fall head first; to turn a somersault; to turn an object with a mouth, e.g. a chaṭu, mouth downward.
of goats, esp. of castrated rams, well developed and sleek looking (can be used alone or with-tan and verb neloḱ).

definition: alone (cf. Hindi bijar).

perplexed, confused (cf. Hindi vyakul, and Uria bikoro. See also akul-bakul).
to spread out e.g. a mat; to stand on its legs e.g. a bed, stool, chair, table; of the artificial spur of a cock, to be turned on its side (and hence unable to cut) (passive form).
an awe inspiring appearance of deep water (also bi-bi).
a cat.

subwords.sub_definition: a jungle herb, prob- ably Lepidagathis fasciculata. Nees, Acanthaceae, H.104/21/5, B.104/22 ('a diffuse aromatic viscous hairy herb among rocks in wisdomsal forests').

the name of a bush about 4-5 feet high. The leaves are used for scrubbing dishes. It has a black fruit (not eaten) at the hook-like extensions; Martynia diandra, Glox., Pedaliaceae, H. 103/3/1, B.103/1 (H. also gives an English name, 'Devil's Claw').

definition: a cat, also spelled bilae.
a mixed black and white colour of chickens.
an egg.
magic.

definition: a snake; pass. to be attacked by a snake (in prayers the form Biṅa is sometimes used in the formula mera Kula mera Biṅa, may no tiger attack, may no snake attack') (N.B. coiled snakes are believed to serve as stools for spirits).

subwords.sub_definition: an eel (a fish with a snake like mouth) form.
snake poison.

a plant with long spotted leaves. Its root and leaves are used as medicine for snake bite. $
a plant also called Sim Ukut́ Reht́ or Kuit́ Rama Reht́, q.v.
the name of a deep pit of water in the jungles near the village of Petapiṭi.
a snake charmer.
a kind of small inedible mushroom.

a kind of thick white froth, about as big as a hockey ball, found (esp. In the beginning of the rainy season) on water and occasionally on land, believed to be vomited up by snakes. (Much smaller than this is Chanḍuḱ beć, q.v.).

definition: a harp (used in translating, not a Ho word).

the circular object (plaited straw, a cloth) which a woman puts on her head to help balance a load; the circular mat (made of palm leaves, straw, or Erasiṅ) used to support circular earthen pots on the ground; to form something, e.g. a cloth, in a circular way; of stacking paddy on the threshing floor, to stack in a circular pattern.

subwords.sub_definition: a rice bundle in which the outer ropes (bandi baver) are tied into a small circular rope at the top.
to stack in a circular pattern (when stacking paddy on the threshing floor.

definition: to be stretched out in a slightly wavy way, e.g.of a snake, rope, cloth (see also linda-londo).
daru several trees as follows (for more details consult the description of each tree given in its proper place in the dictionary.

the papaya tree.
a shrub with red and green leaves and with red flowers.
-same as jara bindi daru.
the Physic Nut tree.

definition: poetic parallel of Nageèra, q.v.
putam a variety of pigeon which the villagers identify as the Common Green Pigeon.
a spider fu.

spider lick, a burn-like skin irritation supposedly caused by the urine of a spider.
same as bindīram chãi, q.v.
same as bindīram rēd, q.v.

a bugle.
a winding e.g. in a road (verbal noun of biwr).

definition: prayer, to pray.

to intercede for, intercession.

a wild cat.
a name given by some to a low (1-2 ft.) shrub with leaves which are white and green and by others to the pisi: bindi daru, q.v.
an uncastrated male jungle bison.
see guni honko.
used in prayers as poetic parallel with ote ili, q.v., having the same meaning.
the barking deer (muntjak), also called silib.
a type of juguni spirit which inflicts harm on animals (as rankani juguni inflicts harm on people).

sometimes used to refer to a silib.
a jungle creeper with leaves very much resembling those of the mur daru also called nai mur, q.v. в.
toward the jungle; a bowel movement (in town areas bārpā would be more commonly used for this); to have a bowel movement.
a wild dog (usually called tani).
a jungle fowl.

a wild boar.
a plant also called buru sursu Aaḱ or buru mani Aaḱ.
sometimes used to refer to a murum, a nilgai.

poetic parallel of uṭa (In Munda this is the common word used for 'to rise').

to brandish e.g. a battle-axe twisting and turning it when fighting; the flashing of light off such twisting objects; flashiness (in a more broad sense); an object, e.g. a blunted arrow, falling in a twisting and turning way.
delay; to delay; to spend an unduly long time over.
a poison which some hunters put on their arrowheads.
poison; pass. to be poisoned; used figuratively with the same meaning as bisi-data.

human semen (not mage kaji).
words which cause harm to others, esp. by casting spells upon them, cf. a daṭa.

definition: a measure of grains equal to 20 poyla, roughly 20 seers.
poisonous.
social uncleanness; to cause or contract social uncleanness.

subwords.sub_definition: naughty (e.g. of children).
same as bisić-biṭal, q.v.
impure, morally unclean.
to defile.
to include in defilement; pass. to share defilement, e.g. the Manḍi-Chaṭu of those descending from a common ancestor (counting back about four generations) after the death of one person of the group.

definition: disgust created by squalor and filth.
a hawk, probably the Sparrow-Hawk, much like the richi, the Shikra, except that it has stouter feet, shorter toes and paler colouration.
to disturb, e.g. hornets, bees, fishes, so as to cause them to fly or swim about excitedly; to disturb someone who is quiet; to irritate a small wound so that it grows.

definition: a hawk, see bisiri.

to plant (by digging a hole, etc.); to erect by planting; refl. -of a plough, to dig (itself) into the ground at too deep an angle so that it cannot move along properly; as used with bōḱ and kaṭa see below.

on tiptoes (with verbs of walking or standing).
to plant more plants or seedlings among others, e.g. because the others are coming up too far apart (rowa-bolo is used in the same way).

a type of gonyor tree which has weak wood compared to the jaṅ gongor tree which has stronger wood used for making axe handles, bed-frames, yokes, etc.

to start to eat or drink again after someone has not been able to eat because of sickness (referring to food in general or to some particular food forbidden because of the sickness, see also jom-biṭal); used along with or parallel to bisiḱ meaning 'morally unclean'.
inside, within.

detraction, calumniation.

property, possessions; to acquire possessions.

definition: to turn one's buttocks toward someone, e.g. a small child toward the mother to clean after defecating; to do so toward someone in scorn, derision or anger $.

subwords.sub_definition: same as bituć.

definition: to turn around; to wind around (e.g. of a circuitous road); to revolve, spin or whirl around, e.g. on a potter’s wheel; to return, e.g. something borrowed.

subwords.sub_definition: to get or find by wind- ing around; to divine by having someone spin around sitting on a padki, a large poyla.

definition: to feel a spinning sensation in the head; to feel giddy proud to thov Bil.

subwords.sub_definition: to look up from the top of the eyes with the head bent down and somewhat sidewards; used as an adjective in reviling someone who tends to look in this way.

definition: the sound made by a snake gliding showly along the ground (with a verb of motion).
a large thick-headed fish about a yard long and a foot thick with a white underbelly and dark back.
an open space in some straight surface, e.g. an embankment, one's front teeth (where a tooth is missing) (see also bonka); to make the same. Passive -to have the same.
to peel off the bark of tender branches do.
same as boć- boć(tan).

subwords.sub_definition: very straight and high (of a tree, see also bojo-bojo (tan)).

definition: to be chipped at the rim, e.g. a plate, axe; to have the tip broken off, e.g. of a cow's horn; to break, tear, cut off a piece, e.g. of a plate.
the Golden Oriole (a bird).
used in prayers parallel to kaji, a word, a spoken assurance or promise.
year (in songs, etc. sirma is the proper Ho word for year.

subwords.sub_definition: the completion of the yearly cycle (e.g. for some crop, $.

definition: oe the name of a bird, the Golden Oriole (also bochoḱ).
an uncastrated he-goat.

subwords.sub_definition: a very big black ant (see -ken).
a small (1-2 ft. high) kūyad-like plant with toothed leaves. It is used for medicine (called boda perhaps in reference to its smell) na.
same as bodaken tonto, q.v.

definition: manure, fertilizer, to apply fertilizer.
quickly, soon (used independently or as verbal affix).
to exchange, to change, instead of.

subwords.sub_definition: to change back, to convert.

definition: respected elders who give advice in panchayats, etc.
see bõysor.
to crack open so that the contents go out, e.g of a chaṭu or of a leaf containing something.
to spurt out (much but pulsating, not in a steady stream, with verbs hari and the like).
an oil lamp made by putting oil and a cloth into a leaf cup (chakudiḱ or puḱ), used only for ritual purposes.
to cut through soft earth easily, esp. of the plough but also of a kudali, etc.
a bag.
the condition of a silkworm (lungam chidu) becom- ing fully grown after changing its skin four times.

subwords.sub_definition: to perform some sacrifice when separating the cocoons from the branches after the silkworms have changed their skin four times.

definition: reward (bogsis).
the color of a hen. white and light brown.

head; a leader; the part of a tank, pond, etc. where the water enters; a man's height (when measuring the depth of water, e.g. bar bohḱ twice the height of a man); to face one's head or the head of some object, e.g. a bed, in a certain direction.

subwords.sub_definition: to let down one's hair.
same as bohḱ hataṅ.
hair of the human head; pass. verb of one's hair to grow, (e.g. to a certain height).
a part in one's hair.
to stand on one's head.
to feel a spinning sensation in the head, to feel giddy de.
same as boḱ biyun- biyun.
a honey comb, the cells of which are full of honey; of cattle, sheep, goats, etc. to stagger around in a daze because of weakness or a serious wound.
the brain, also called merely hataṅ or ataṅ.
to pull the hair, e.g. bohḱć heeht́ ket́ińa, she pulled my hair.
a skull.

South, referring to the position of the head of a buried person. Hos bury North-Sount with the head to the South, so that the body is facing North (should it sit up), the direction from which their ancestors have come.
reaching to the top of one's head, e.g. of the depth of water.
the leaders.

definition: a load; a bundle of wood, leaves, etc. tied together.
very straight and fairly long; of an arrow, to go very straight (cf. boć-boć(tan)).
baba a variety of paddy of which the grains are long and slender.
see indurmuti bojormuti.
a sound made by a ram when chasing a goat.
a stupid person.
to unwittingly wound someone with e.g. the point of a knife or arrow, a protuding piece of wood, etc.
same as buka Aaḱ, q.v.
younger brother/sister.

subwords.sub_definition: the husband of one's younger sister (as distinct from hon ara, q.v.).
children of the same parents (also undi-bóyа).
younger sister (same as undi kui).

definition: the Bakain or Persian Lilac tree, Melia Azedarach, L., Meliaceae, H.40/7/2, B.40/6.
same as bokon- bokon, q.v.

subwords.sub_definition: to be long bodied, e.g. of a deer, horse, cattle; to be stretched out long, e.g. the tail of the lan bird; used also of fish moving (stretched out) along the surface of water.

definition: a bird, the Tree Pie. This makes a sound like, bokorliań and eats silkworms.
bearded (used only with boda, an uncastrated he-goat).
the sound of boiling water bubbling (when rice is being cooked, or when water alone is being boiled).
to enter.

subwords.sub_definition: to enter inside.
to certainly enter.
to defile by entering.
to enter and remain still or quiet; to enter and stay there (refl. form).
to enter so as to be deeply embedded, e.g. of the feet of cattle in watery mud.
to enter straight in.
to enter and find.
to enter among: to enter into oH.
to enter in large numbers.

definition: a tree considered by some villagers to be the biggest tree, not found locally but found in the big jungles of Orissa and in the Saranda jungle. Also called gomor mari daru, and called uruko goć daru since it is believed that when it flowers insects, birds, etc. who sit under it die. It is used for medicine.
to make a wide gaping hole, e.g. in an embankment (also ban-bon).
a hill (jungle) in Orissa, mentioned in prayers.
to close (from Hindi), used in certain metaphorical usages, e.g. paeṭić bondo ket́a, 'He closed down the work'.
to render someone's power ineffectual; to put an end to one's power. Pass. of one's power, to be rendered ineffectual, to come to an end.
flat tasteless rice-beer (almost like ḍunḍuḱ Daḱ, water in which rice has been cooked).

a streamer; to hang a rather long piece of cloth or paper to the top of a long stick, so that it seems to be flying in the air; to tie a long thread with a piece of cloth or paper to the rear portion of a bird (cf. also chandol, less long than bonḍol). $

subwords.sub_definition: the male Paradise Fly-Catcher (a bird with a very long tail).

definition: to bind or restrict by means of mantras (from Hindi bandhan).

subwords.sub_definition: to block or check.

definition: a spirit; to sacrifice; (the name of a spirit to whom a sacrifice is offered usually takes the affix $ re, e.g. punḍi sanḍi Siṅgbonga reko bongaića. 'they offer a white cock to Siṅgbonga).

subwords.sub_definition: to call into by some rite of divining, e.g. a spirit who does not otherwise enter when called at the time of a kea-ader ceremony.
same as bonga danda.

by a sacrifice to turn back some harm upon another, e.g 1) upon a witch who is inflicting harm on another, 2) upon the people of another village who have driven out (bonga-enḍaḱ) a spirit who has now moved into the village of those who are sending it back.
a generic term for traditional sacrifices to the spirits.
the bamboo staff used by one who goes into a trance for the purposes of divining emoa.
rice beer made for sacrificial offerings, which is therefore considered sacred and can only be drunk by certain people.
the Black or King Vulture (also called rilaṅ didi and sanḍi didi).
to get rid of (e.g. sickness or a spirit inflicting sickness) by performing a sacrifice.
to kill some animal for sacrificial purposes.
people who offer sacrifices (referring esp. to the diuri who performs the sacrifice but also to those who call upon him to do so).
the Milky Way.
by a sacrifice to preserve the life of a man apparently dying.
the meat of an animal which has been sacrificed. This is considered sacred and can by eaten only by certain people.
adj. with diri, a crystal- lized smooth whitish glass-like stone, also bonga laḱtadaḱ -such a stone.
to exhause oneself performing sacrifices (refl. form).
a poisoning of someone done through the intermediation of some spirit.
to find out (e.g. what spirit is afflicting someone and what must be offered to that spirit) by sacrificial processes or by divining, e.g. haṭaḱ gosoḱ.
to drive out a spirit.

while dreaming to have the impression that one is unable to move or even breathe because of (the shadow of) a spirit who is standing quite close by and sometimes seen in a dream (cf. ota -to press down).

a climbing shrub often used to make chakuli (a rough flat network of strong twine in a round frame used for carrying earth, etc. at the end of a pole); prob. Ventilago maderaspatana, Gaertn. Rhamnaceae, H.46/1/1 and V. calyculata, Tul., H.46/1/2,.
same as bonga sarjom, q.v.
the magea spirits who look after (gupi) the animals of the jungle. Hunters offer them ganja or pika to dull their brains, so that the hunt may succeed on.

a falling star (as though spirits are shooting arrows at one another). There is a belief that the spirit indwelling Singa-so Buru, about 10-15 miles S.E. of Chaibasa, fired an arrow and burned Chari Buru, near Khuntpani.
same as bonga tore.
to divine using a winnowing basket.
to sacrifice again (after some long interval, e.g. one year) e.g. on the annual Honbah feast or when someone who is sick has not recovered after the first sacrifice.
a kind of beetle which when tied to a twig keeps gyrating around making a loud buzzing sound.
to take up (e.g. a banai) by means of divining gear.

definition: to have an open space in some small surface, e.g.one's teeth where a tooth is missing (for which the form daṭam bonka yana can be used) (see also boaṅ which has much the same meaning but which can also refer to a bigger open space, e.g. a break in an embankment).
to tie something with a slip-knot.
headship, leadership; responsibility for some work (verbal noun of bohḱ)
an entering, an entrance (verbal noun of bolo).

subwords.sub_definition: a door or gate for entering (e.g. bajar reaḱ boṉolo duar, the gate of the city).

definition: to unwind or stretch out thread; to unwrap silk-cocoons, to stretch out, e.g. a muffler, length-wise; refl. to stretch oneself out (e.g. a worm or a snake).

subwords.sub_definition: an edible leaf (vegetable) found growing wildly and extensively over fields at about the time of the start of the monsoon, much like mui: Aaḱ but longer ack cloth;.
to unwind or unreel.
to unwind upward, e.g. the thread around a sayū dumbu which at the time of burial is stretched up from a corpse to the air above od.

definition: having a slppery surface; of the feet, not to get a good foothold because the surface is too slippery.

subwords.sub_definition: a chora (q.v.) type fish, slippery to hold on to.
a smooth-seed variety of rambā called urid in Hindi, Phaseolus mungo, L., incl. var. roxburgii, Prain, Papilionaceae, H.53/49/8-9, B53/90.
a plant resembling the tempa Aaḱ plant, called bōr since its leaves, esp. when cooked are very slippery in the hand Bollabba).
of the feet, to slip back because a surface is too slippery.

definition: a snake apparently the same as Hoffman's buru ganḍai -a hooded snake with erect poison fangs. The neck is dilatable, but less than that of the cobra. This snake is yellow and dark brown. Its belly is yellow and black towards the tail (also called borbunḍae, gorgunḍae).
a bird, the Tree Pie, also called bokor-lian and bukur-lian).
a straw rope.

subwords.sub_definition: a piece of straw rope, an end of which is kept smouldering as a source of fire.
an opening between two successive rounds of a straw rope wound around something, e.g. a bandi.
of water, muddy, to make muddy; of eyesight, blurred; to make blurred; pass. to become blurred.

definition: a mouth in which some front teeth are lost, broken, etc, (sometimes said in jest of babies) -.
Bharbharia village.
a snake, same as borgunḍai, q.v.
of a section of something, e.g. the horn of a cow, to break off.
a spear (also bursi).
same as borkaw, q.v.
the lungs.

fear, to fear; to be afraid. When the object of the fear is not ex- pressed, this is used transitively, sete.g. boro ket́ać, 'He was afraid', alom boroya (boro-e-a), 'Don't be afraid'. When the object of fear is expressed it takes a te or a marker, e.g. alom borotekowa or alom borowakowa, 'Do not be afraid of them'. Boro is used in an impersonal construction with the experiencer as object, e.g. et́ka boro ket́ińa, 'I was thoroughly scared. It is also sometimes used with a personal subject and a direct personal object with the meaning of 'to make someone give in (give up) out of fright $.

subwords.sub_definition: to scare causing one to be startled.
to frighten, startle.
timid, frightened; in a timid or frightened way prod.
to scare causing to run about in panic.
to 'die' of fright, i.e. to be very much frightened (refl. form).
to frighten (causitive form) doels) reqs (add.
to cause someone to become very still and quiet out of fear; pass. to become still and quiet out of fear at mosiog.
to cause someone to experience deep-felt fear; pass. to experience deep-felt fear.
a coward.
reverential fear; to show reverential fear.

definition: an alternate form of bor, a straw rope.
same as boṛo-bunji, q.v.
same as boṛo-bunji, q.v.
to make a boiling sound (also bokoṛo-bokoṛo).
to be very dirty (of water, e.g. mixed with soft mud; dol-dol means much the same, bora is used of less dirty water).

a sacrifice to which the whole village community contributes performed at the time of some epidemic of men or cattle, or even if there is no epidemic, performed about twice a year to ward off (or drive out) the baram and juguni.spirits; a jungle picnic.
of Ḍiaṅ, to turn bad because of the heat; of men, to become sick because of the heat.
poetic form of bōḱ, head.
to boil up e.g of water when fully boiling (bubbling $.
used in prayers, etc. as poetic parallel of gitiḱ, 'to sleep'; used in prayers parallel to kolom, 'a threshing floor'.
a fast; to fast; sometimes used in expression kaṭab-boron (also baran).
rather (following the preferred person or action, e.g. am boroncho senoḱme, 'rather you go' [than someone else); Manḍi boroncho jomem, 'rather eat food' [than drink rice beer]).

subwords.sub_definition: to shake with fear.
refl. form to withdraw (back up) out of fear.
fearful, frightening.

definition: nephew, i.e. sister's child (used in the Goelkera area, ge is the usual Ho word for this).
the custard apple tree (so called near Noamundi; near Chaibasa called dambau or mandal; near Balandia called maya), see dambau.
courage, to have courage, to encourage.

subwords.sub_definition: to encourage, embolden.

definition: an annual wage given e.g. to a lohar for keeping the ploughshares, axes, etc. sharpened. In this case the whole salary is given once a year, in contrast to pankira, q.v.
an ancestral line or family.

subwords.sub_definition: an ancestral line for generations.

definition: a word used in a story with the prob. meaning of 'to sit', (not a Ho word, prob. from Uria, see baṭilo).
smallpox.
a sack, bag.

subwords.sub_definition: sack cloth; clothing made of sacks (worn as a sign of repentance).

definition: very cheap (also sosta).
to spoil; to render ineffective (from Hindi 'bhrasht', 'spoilt').
poetic parallel with Bamee, 'brahmin'. Sometimes used of those who bring buffaloes, etc. from other places for sale.
a Chaṭu of water raised up on a pole by Kumhars to appease spirits so that they will not send rain and spoil their work.
to satisfy or please a spirit by some offering or victim (used in prayers).

subwords.sub_definition: to put the required materials (e.g. golanchi flowers and small clay statues of men inside compartments marked off with brick powder or coal powder) inside a place (e.g. a house) from which an evil spirit, (e.g. don churdu bonga) is to be driven out. (It is believed that the spirit will be attracted to these and can then be driven out with them).

definition: a long big log of cut wood (cf. muṭu, a small log).
to stretch out something long and straight.
a bird which attacks silkworms, prob. another name for the bokorlian, the Tree Pie.
a loin cloth; to put a loin cloth on someone; refl. -to wear a loin cloth.
long, used e.g. of houses, ropes; also, to stretch something out lengthwise, e.g. a rope, a sari.
to incessantly complain in a scolding way, to nag.

of animals, esp. cattle, to swim or glide through water with the head bobbing up; of men, to swim or tread water in a way resembling cattle swimming through water; of fish or snakes, to swim through water with a small part of the body showing above the water.
an uncastrated buffalo or bison; occasionally used of an exceptionally big bull (cf. andia, biar); of men, to run wild (not doing any work, with no sense of responsibility) like a boyar.
used by a woman in addressing some male child or young man, cf. bui.
the month of 'baisak', last half of April and the first half of May.
a full-grown young buffalo Tome.
an exclamation to a very small child to warn him to stay away from a fire.

a round bundle of rope (e.g. a roll of rope used for making beds, etc.); to roll up rope into a round bundle, e.g. bör buime, 'roll the straw rope into a round bundle'; the term hasa bu means a clod of earth.

subwords.sub_definition: a round bundle of rope.

definition: something which makes someone drunk, an intoxicant (see bul).
to come out in a thick cloud or mass, e.g. smoke (with verb moḱ) or white ants emerging from a hole (with verb olt́).
to cause to float on the top of water; to rise up to the surface of water (e.g. paddy stalks when reploughing, clothes being washed).

subwords.sub_definition: to cause to float away on the surface of water ni baan).
to rise to the surface of water.
to come rising up to the surface of water.

definition: a musical instrument (a cord or rope stretched out over a piece of bamboo connected to a type of resounding box made of bamboo, when plucked it resounds).
to cut off the tail feathers of a chicken, bird, etc.

subwords.sub_definition: a chicken with broken or cut off tail feathers.

definition: to wear one's waist clothes loose, so that they hang low (esp of children).
shrewdness; intelligence; knowledge; to plan something shrewdly.
old woman; wife; pass. to become an old woman.

subwords.sub_definition: pass. to become an extremely old woman.
an old woman; sometimes said in jest of a bear.
water in which rice has been cooked which has been kept over for a second day (used in South Singhbhum).
an absolutely full moon.

definition: a tiny slender fish, about ½ inch long, the smallest fish known around Chaibasa ($.

to move along smoothly partly submerged in water or covered by earth, e.g. a plough; figur. to feel the sensation of a louse moving (ploughing) through one's hair, e.g. bōḱ-balere siku budu-buduńtana.
Wednesday.
small mouthed (used esp. of children, sometimes jokingly or as a nickname).
of rice, half-cooked.
good; to heal; to treat well, to be kind to; pass. to get well.

subwords.sub_definition: blessed.
blessed.
esp. of children, small animals, etc. to be well proportioned, beautiful.

definition: good; to heal, to treat well, to be kind to; Pass. -to get well.

subwords.sub_definition: in a good place; in a vital spot (e.g. a spot in which an animal is shot causing quick death.

definition: to make good or well again; to remove possibly harmful effects, e.g. of unfavourable omens.
well filled out, sleek looking (used esp. of goats).
a form of address to a girl or a young woman (used by a man or a woman).
a form of address to a girl or a young woman, (bui+a).
a member of the Buia community.
a village doctor.
to bark.
to make a hole through something.

subwords.sub_definition: of clothes, to have a hole through exposing the buttocks.
a hole through which something passes, e.g. water Joe.

definition: a herb, grown in water and used for curry. In some places called boka Aaḱ and said to be called losod Aaḱ in Mundari, prob. Limnophila gratioloides, Br. Scrophulariaceae, B.98/12, H.98/ 13/7.
of spring water, to bubble up rapidly.
to be dissatisfied with (and therefore not willing to take) something because of some deficiency in it (this can take a -te form, e.g. Jiluć bukutea, 'He is dissatisfied with the meat').
a large black beetle about 2 inches long with 6 circular dots (3 on each side).
the Tree Pie, a bird, also called bokorlian; a cry of the same bird, said to be heard esp on days when it will rain.
of the plough, to cut easily through soft soil (e.g. shortly after a rainfall when the soil is still soft) (used with verbs of ploughing).

subwords.sub_definition: same bukud (leka).

definition: to make drunk/intoxicated; pass. - to become drunkard.

to win around to one's purposes; to win around e.g. one who is angry or pouting (see also babo); to call someone (Hindi 'bulana', proper Ho would be kea); to be completely engrossed e.g. in drinking rice-beer.
a very powerful churdu bonga, q.v. ed an.
the thigh.
salt.

subwords.sub_definition: rain coming from the sea (said to stunt the growth of crops).
same as bulun tasad.
same as bulun tasad.
a herb with 3-6 (usually 4-5) grained spikes growing close to the earth. Eleusine aegyptiaca, Desf., Gramineae, B.139/19, H.139/22/3.

definition: a fish about 3 inches long, esp. narrow toward the head and tail.
a member of the Bhumij tribe (also called Mutukan in Ho.
a rash or a measles type; measles.
the sound made by the bonga uru; the buzzing sound made by a flying tree beetle, (malan uru).
a jackal of a big variety.
a gun.

subwords.sub_definition: a beautiful and well-known plant scrambling among bushes. Its flowers pass from a yellow to a red colour. A medicine is made from the roots, said to be poison, which is applied externally on wounds. Gloriosa superba, L., Liliaceae, B.145/8 H.145/10/1.
the flower of the bunum kuchun daruntowa.
the edible mushroom which grows in the bunum.

definition: a small or middle-sized tree of the jungles with beautiful flowers, white or variously coloured, which are edible. The seeds of this tree are used in the sacrifice of the mage porob, Bauhinia variegata, L., Caesalpiniaceae, H.54/4/5, Β.54/6.
an ant hill, to make an ant hill.

subwords.sub_definition: the meat of the thigh of some animal.
the queen white ant.
see bunum kucuṅ.
the hole through which the shaft (hisi dandaḱ) is connected to a plough.

definition: to sink the teeth into something soft.

subwords.sub_definition: to quickly sink the teeth into something soft.

definition: the husks of certain grains such as kansari; see also mad bura.
to draw or ladle out grains or water from a larger mass.
a cotton-like substance found in the seed capsule of certain plants, e.g. edel buram; of soil, to be very soft and loose e.g. after receiving much fertilizer.
to wipe out, to destroy completely.
stupid fellow (Hindi), used in reviling someone.
same as barbur, q.v.
bubbles; to form bubbles, e.g. air bubbling out of a puncture hole in a tube put under water.
to have a high spot or lump protruding above the general level of a field (see also barchat́-burchut́).
flying ant (this form is used esp. by children).
flying ant (more common form is burdut́).

subwords.sub_definition: small nosed (said affectionately or jokingly of small children).

definition: a flying ant (the winged female of white ants which swarm out of ant-hills of the earth esp. at the beginning of the monsoon)

subwords.sub_definition: the queen white ant (also called bunum enga) nemo.
a name given to the sarli thorn because used in the leaf-bag (kokomba) used to trap flying ants.

definition: one of the many sounds ascribed to the obor oe, the Indian Cuckoo and/or the Hawk Cuckoo or Brainfever bird (Hoffman gives burim suigud as a cry of the Brainfever bird and suggests this as the equivalent of the English 'brain-fever') $.
daru a name used in some areas for the tree more commonly called būnju daru, q.v., at least in the Chaibasa area.
a swelling (tumour) on the back of the head, neck, etc.; a knot of a tree.
the 'hukka' (hubble-bubble) rarely seen in present day Ho villages.
a large tree of the jungle, 30-50 ft. high with thick branches and bitter bark; possibly Hymanodictyon excelsum, Wall., Rubiaceae, E.M., H.77/7/1, B.77/10.
smouldering, used esp. with sengel as below.

subwords.sub_definition: a smouldering fire made in a broken Chaṭu or kechoḱ by putting chaff, wood-shavings, etc. for this purpose.

definition: a spear (also borcha).
a jungle bush which is used for making rope and which has an edible fruit; Grewia rothii, DC, Tiliaceae, B.28/8 H.28/4/14.
of blossoms, etc., to come up in great number, close to one-another (cf. also burud- burud, burud-leka); note the expression; panḍu burt́-burt́ of the hair of the head, to be completely white.

a mountain, a hill, a jungle; to heap up (used also as verbal affix with other verbs in this sense, e.g. dul-buru, 'to pour in a heap', note the expression buruken chauli used in prayers as follows, buruken chauli garaken mayomeń punjiama hinjiama 'I put in the punji heaped-up rice grains for you, I cause rivers of blood to flow for you' (i.e. I offer you numerous sacrifices); poetic parallel with bonga a spirit, to sacrifice; as a passive verb, poetic parallel with bonga or goć having the meaning 'to become a spirit' (said e.g. in prayers to the ancestors).

subwords.sub_definition: the foot of a hill (the place where one reaches (beta) a hill or jungle).

hills and low-land, hills and dales. Also buru and bera are used in such terms as buru magea, bera magea honko, 'magea spirits of hill and dale' (sometimes bururenko berarenko and in one prayer buru-berako is used to refer to magea spirits).
a large black snake found in the jungles border.

a spirit of a mountain or high hill. Each high hill near a village has its buru bonga. These are considered benevolent and sacrifices are offered to them at times of drought, etc. They are considered wealthy in grains and cattle and are believed to live in big houses and sometimes to appear in the form of men (see jid bonga).
a member of the shrike genus of birds (cf. chari oe), whitish, probably the Grey Shrike and/or the Baybacked Shrike.
the top of a hill.
some give this for the Racket-tailed Drongo (others give lan danchu:, bindu danchu:).
probably the Yellow-throated Sparrow.
a level section in a jungle above a ravine and between hills.
a jungle pigeon.
probably the Indian Great Horned Owl.
a herb 5-7 ft. high from which flutes are made; appar- ently Peucedanum nagpurensis, Prain (P. glaucum, DC), Umbelli- ferae, B.74/9, H.74/10/3.$
the slope of a hill.
the base of a hill.

a collective word for hills'.
