a shrub resembling but smaller than the golanchi tree and having medicinal usages.
a sharply sloping bank of a river.
a large forest tree sometimes used for silkworm breeding. It has a smooth bark. The Arjun tree, Terminalia arjuna, W&A., Combretaceae, B.62/8, H.62/1/4.
a section of a river where the water is very deep.
a particular thorn bush growing about one ft. high and found near steams or in places where water remains.
a Cormorant (bird); also called daḱ kz. q.v.
a river spirit (see also gara baguti).
a large crab dwelling in rivers.
the Brownheaded Storkbill Kingfisher (bird).
the Little Egret (bird), also called choṭead koḱ.
a tree resembling the kuda (janum) tree, but smaller, and having bitter (heben) fruit. Eugenia heyneana, Wall., Myrtaceae. H.63/1/6, B.63/5.
a very large tiger.
the land along side of a river.
a ravine in which water is running.
the White Wagtail (bird) also called daḱ Sirać, ef. Sirać.
a fish, prob. the same as Sisingi Haku, q.v.

a thorny plant which is used for medicine, prob. Xylosma longifolium, Clos., Flacourtiaceae, B.14/5, H.14/3/1 This is one of many plants used, because of their odour, in divination to protect (kesed) a village or house from harmful action of spirits.

definition: same as gadolać.
the slimy alga found floating up from rocks in ponds during the monsoon; the colour of this (a dark bluish-green).
a throne.
to pile up, heap up, e.g. wood gadi-pereć to heap up fully.
a ravine cut out by water (the form gaḍia is also but less commonly used. See also Lór, Doṛa, Ḍakut́); used in prayers as poetical parallel with Siṅ or Sút́ probably with the meaning here given.
a cart; the wheel of a cart; pass. verb-to be supplied with a cart.

subwords.sub_definition: bus or train fare.
the central part of a wooden wheel into which the spokes are fitted.
a spoke of a wheel.
the planks on the sides of a bullock cart and the poles supporting these.
a cartful.

definition: same as gaḍi, q.v.
green slime found floating on top of stagnant bodies of water (also gadelad).
a ram (around Chaibasa the form goḍora is more commonly used).
a particular drum-beat and tune used for the Bah feast (also called jadur, q.v.).
same as Garuṛu Putam.
a big bluish jungle pigeon, the cry of which sounds like a deep moan, prob. the Blue Rock Pigeon.
to move around slowly, to mope (used e.g. of a thief looking for his opening, or of a dog moping around).
a pickaxe.
a large brass pot sometimes found in the homes of the more wealthy.
an acrid (bitterly pungent) sensation in the mouth caused by eating hadaḱ or the like.
a small monkey, the Rhesus Macaque.

subwords.sub_definition: a name given to kukuru dumbu (q.v.) esp. by children who tie together many of these grasses (with long tufts resembling hairy caterpillars) to form a figure reminding one of a monkey. For a like reason this is also called tuyu (jackal) dumbu.
a tree, probably another name for sanḍaṕ siṅ daru, q.v. (H. gives 'gae-ka-lundi as the Hindi name for his).

a herb resembling kurti, but stretched out much more extensively, and giving smaller thinner pods (some places also called buru kuṛti) Prob. Atylosia scarabaeoides, Benth., Papilionaceae, H.53/36/4, B.53/11.

definition: the carrot, Daucus carota, L. Umbelliferae, H.74/12/1, B.74/5.
of a place, to be dirty. e.g. because of something rotting in a damp place, or because of excrement (also jagaṛa).
to sew (with thread and needle).

subwords.sub_definition: to sew torn clothes by pulling together (without putting patches).

definition: of the sound of one's voice, to be restricted and not clear, e.g. because of a sore throat.

subwords.sub_definition: a variety of the ṭerka bird but making a more muted sound than the ṭer-ṭer sound made by the ṭerka bird.

definition: to plait, e.g. hair, mats.

subwords.sub_definition: to plait compactly.
a plaited hair-knot.

definition: to dirty something with one's dirty hands (used esp. of dirtying dishes).
same as gatat́, q.v.
a mistake; fault; to make a mistake; to commit a fault.
rain; to rain (transitive in form and takes animate subject, i.e. gama ket́ać, 'it rained').

subwords.sub_definition: to rain down (upon) (used also in figurative sense of raining e.g. blessings upon someone).
of rain, to continue throughout the rainy season gama-gama in the rain (while rain continues), e.g. gama-gamać sen tat́a, 'He walked in the rain'.
to make moist by rain.
to make soft by raining upon (e.g. a field).
of rain, to make wet; pass. to become wet by rain.
of rain, to come down heavily for some time (2-3 days) until the new moon (muluḱ) has appeared (used with chanḍuḱ as object).
to rain throughout the year.
to make cool by raining.
of rain, to fall on (someone or something).

definition: to be shy or feel shame; sometimes used with a -tan participial form and a verb 'to go' meaning 'to slink away out of shame.
same as gamá-gamí.
poetic parallel for disum, country, used only in prayers and songs.
a ticklish sensation; to feel a ticklish sensation (Les.26); used as poetic parallel with giyuḱ meaning 'to feel shyness or shame'.

of baby calves, to try to stand up esp. in order to drink the mother's milk; of baby mice, not yet able to see, to move around; of bigger mice or rats, to sniff around here and there esp. in search of food.
a cloth, e.g. such as is worn around the waist when bathing.
of something spoken, to be heeded.
to receive some internal injury without any external wound (e.g. from some blow).
to echo (for which gan-uraa is usually used).

subwords.sub_definition: to echo.

definition: a sledge hammer.
a small round net for catching fish (verbal noun of gari).

four; a unit of four (sometimes used in counting, e.g. cocoons, ie. gelbar ganḍa = 48, ganda = 80; to count by fours; used as poetic parallel to leka, to count'; a finger, a toe; as a measurement one finger the breadth of one finger.

subwords.sub_definition: used in prayers parallel to munda hon possibly with the same meaning 'rich', but more probably with the meaning 'poor'. (see kantar hon).
poetic parallel to leka-misa in prayers, 'count among.
the space between two fingers.
a paw.
knuckless.
when counting a unit of four; as a measure of length-one finger, i.e. the breadth of one finger.

definition: in an oblique line, as opposed to muli (in a straight. line); either directly across (perpendicular to) or at an angle to something straight (muli); to place in an oblique line; to block by placing in an oblique line; refl. -to go off at an angle; to turn to the side (e.g. of a pig turning its head sidewards to bite); in some contexts ganḍi is used for horizontal and muli is used for vertical.

subwords.sub_definition: to block, e.g. a road, by putting across.
same as ganḍi-eset́.
a flute into which one blows from the side (ef. Mulirutu into which one blows directly from the end).
paddy sheaves piled up on a horizontal line on the threshing floor (compare binḍa sarai a circular form).

definition: haze, smog.
a stool (see also banam ganḍu).

subwords.sub_definition: jaw teeth esp. of cattle (see Tanagoćdaṭa for the molars of men).
a prickly herb with prominent yellow flowers and prickly leaves with white veins, prob. Argemone mexicana, L., Papa-veraceae, B.8/1, H.8/2/1 (called also Mani Janum and Tayan daṭa janum).
a wooden stool.
a rope stool.

definition: a large silib, deer (for ganḍua Hoffman gives 'a buck').
the Ganges river, (referred to in prayers) ganga-goya the Ganges river (a term used in prayers).
maize or bajra' as followsḱ-.

subwords.sub_definition: maize (corn).
bajra.
pop-corn.

thin pins made from Tilae Gangai stalks, such as are used for sewing together leaf plates and cups; a thicker section of Tilae Gangai stalks (before being split. into pins) such as is used to cut the umbilical cord after a birth.
someone who exerts great efforts to get something (as a crow (Káḱ) does to get Gangai).
the stalk of the Gangai plant.
same as Gangai Carić. q.v.

definition: see Gangara rambaa.

subwords.sub_definition: a kind of rambaa (a green gram) growing on a creeper, also called Goḍa rambaa. This usually has white seeds. Vigna catjang, Endl., var. typica. H.53/50/ 3, B.53/115.

definition: a kind of grasshopper, usually green in colour.

subwords.sub_definition: same as gangu.

definition: a stone oil press (the ordinary village wooden oil press is called Janti).
a substance grown in fields which when mixed with cigarettes (Pika) and smoked has a drugging effect, hemp (Hindi-ganja).
a banyan (undershirt, T-shirt); refl. to put on a ganji.
a four cornered (at the mouth and base) basket (larger than a fopaḱ and smaller than a Ḍala Gantaḱ).
a small bell (e.g. of a cycle; for a big bell ganṭa is used).
a wound; to wound; to cut up some surface; to cut the soil with a plough.

subwords.sub_definition: of a wound, to be filled with puss with the skin rotting away.

definition: tomorrow.

subwords.sub_definition: a day or two from now.

definition: of a dog, jackal, etc., to slink away with the tail tucked in between the legs; of a man, to try to conceal himself or slink away out of fear or shame (with verb sen, etc.).
some days from now.
the day after (some day already referred to).

subwords.sub_definition: the day after that.
to put off to the following day; to procrastinate.
until the third day (the same as gapater jaket́ or apé ma jaket́).

definition: to tuck up, to hold up one's clothes e.g. when crossing a river.
to make lines, e.g. on a paper, into a piece of wood; to layout the compartments for the punji of a sacrifice; lines so made.
a paste made of mud or cement for building purposes, mortar.

subwords.sub_definition: a mud-paste used for mortar in building.

definition: side shoots, children (used esp. in prayers and songs, otherwise form Gãa, q.v., is more common); the expression sona-gara is used as a collective noun for gold and other such precious metals.
the sound of many people, cattle, sheep, goats, etc. running (with verb nir or saḍi); the sound of many objects overturning, etc.
a rumbling sound of thunder; a rumbling noise in the stomach; to make such a sound.
used referring to desauli in prayers, e.g. in terms Hatu-Garam and Garam Gaetiri (from Hindi gram).

subwords.sub_definition: spirits of various villages (a term used in prayers).

definition: verbal affix to one's heart's content, satisfyingly, satisfactorily (Les.27) ańaḱ Oaḱ re garaṅ, 'in my very house'; after ká/ka garaṅ ofteṅ means 'very much', e.g. ka garaṅeć jom ket́a, he ate very much. (ká angal is also used in this way).
same as gaṛa-guṛu.
pregnant (of animals).
pus (also Sondoro, Mata).
to gape here and there (e.g. of a baby just learning to see). N.B. the form gárgúrtia referring to a baby would mean that he has reached the stage where he starts to gape about looking at things.
to rake together e.g. dirt into a heap; to scoop up together, e.g. fish into a net.

subwords.sub_definition: to rake together into a large heap.
to rake level.

definition: a small shed made for one watching silk-worm breeding (usually branches covered by thatch).

a delay; to delay; to be late; to keep someone waiting (for), e.g. kań gáṛimea, 'I won't keep you waiting', Ḍiaṅ kań gáṛimea, 'I won't keep you waiting for rice-beer; after a participial form with a kee aspect marker means 'right after', e.g. enać em kee gáṛi, right after he will put it'.

subwords.sub_definition: after a little while.
for some time.

definition: a cage.
a big bluish jungle pigeon (around Chaibasa called Gaḍuru Putam, q.v.).
a prostrate and rooting much-branched herb with clusters of tiny white flowers, Alternanthera sessilis, Br., Amarantaceae, B.108/4, H.108/9/1.
a light breeze (also gese-gese).
of leaves, fruit, grains, etc. when fully ripe, to fall to the ground; of loose teeth, one's hair, to fall out; of the Bahgitil (afterbirth) to come out; of a porcupine, to shed its quills.

subwords.sub_definition: of leaves on a tree, to be thinned out by falling (used in pass.form).
used in prayes parallel to jaṅ-nam in the pass. meaning 'to receive as much as could be hoped for in the process of separating the grains from the stalk' (while threshing) (see nam).

definition: to scrub clean (e.g. cooking utensils).

subwords.sub_definition: to scrub clean.

definition: a member of the Gansi community.

subwords.sub_definition: a name used at least in some villages for a game of tag; the one who is 'it' is called 'Gã́si'.
a collective noun for Gansis and others who do menial work; used in prayers for servant spirits of Maraṅbonga and other important spirits.
a large wild dog which reputedly attacks cattle.

definition: to pass wind; to fart.

subwords.sub_definition: to make go out (drive out) by passing wind.

definition: a bamboo contraption to which a kumbad is attached for catching fish; to catch fish with this.
a place on a road where people sometimes gather (used alone or in term Hora Gáṭa. N.B. a mountain pass is Gáṭi).
same as gatat́.
same as gatat́.
up to, inclusive (in expressions such as baro gatad, 'the two of them').
to link up with others in a dancing line; poetic parallel of Juḍi, a friend, to befriend.

subwords.sub_definition: to lead interlinked dancers into e.g. the dancing Akaḍa.
to select as a dancing partner.
to admit someone into a line of dancers; parallel to juri-tala it would mean to admit (someone) as a friend.
to link up e.g. two lines of dancers.

definition: a mountain pass.
a form of rheumatism or arthritis in which pain is felt at the joints, and in which one cannot straighten up nor turn his head properly.
a member of the Gaur or Gope caste.

subwords.sub_definition: the King Crow or Black Drongo, so called because of its habit of accompanying cattle so that it might eat insects which they disturb as they move along (also called merely Dánchut́).
a woman of the Gaur or Gope community, the Hoopoe bird (a local name e.g. in Bhrbharia, see Docot́ Dumbi).
a feast held in some villages at which rice beer is given to the cow-herders.
a chicken provided for those who help out (often members of the Gau caste) at times of Bapala, marriage, etc.

definition: a distance of about two miles.
a mother's younger sister; the wife of one's father's younger brother; one's father's other wife (younger than one's mother).
the younger sister of one's mother-in-law; the wife of the younger brother of one's father-in-law.
a kingdom (used in a story, not commonly heard).
porob a cattleshed feast, esp. that held annually at Chaibasa.
witness; to give witness.

subwords.sub_definition: to give witness.
to witness; a witness.

definition: to beckon to; to lightly run the fingers across something with a gesture of beckoning.
a eunuch.
an irritating sensation at the base of the tongue which causes an inclination to cough.
to move or slink about in a slow stealthy manner (see also gaelaṅ-guiluṅ).

subwords.sub_definition: see gaelaṅ-guiluṅ.

definition: a tree (Hindi Dhaman) which provides good wood for the frames of village beds, plough shafts, etc. Grewia tiliaefolia, Vahl., Tiliaceae H.28/4/8 (gives gonger), B.28/4.
a duck.

a man's sister's child; a man's wife's brother's child; Note verb usage- en hapanum okonrekô gee tat́ića? Where did they make that young woman a niece (sister's child)? i.e. where did they marry her mother? (where was her mother from?).

subwords.sub_definition: a man's sister's son; a man's wife's brother's son.
a man's sister's daughter, a man's wife's brother's daughter.

definition: a kind of potokeć, q.v. (a puffball) (form Gẽṛe also used).
used esp. by children for the Gegétereṅ, q.v.
a kind of bitter burning sensation in the tongue and the back of the throat from eating e.g. Hadaḱ not properly cooked.
a kind of small harmless centipede about an inch long which gives off a scent if touched.
of a wound, to be filled with thick puss; of muddy earth, to be stamped down so as to be sticky.
of writing, to be difficult to read because of overwriting, smudges, etc.
regularly giving trouble to others; obstinate; to frequently harass others.
to have sores on the corner of the mouth.

subwords.sub_definition: a mouth with sores on the corner.

definition: to cheat or commit a foul in a game.
ten (short form).

subwords.sub_definition: twelve; sometimes used figuratively meaning 'many', e.g. gelbar Met́ gelbar Lutur tekô goṅ ket́ića, 'They gave her in marriage with the cooperation of many people' (12 eyes, 12 ears); in a prayer addressed to a spirit, gelbar met́tema, gelbar luturtema, You are very well informed' (12 eyes, 12 ears).

definition: an ear of any kind of grain; of a grain, to form ears.

subwords.sub_definition: to put the ears of one stalk (of paddy) facing those of another stalk (e.g. when laying out stalks on the kolom for threshing).
a term sometimes used for Tilae Gangai (Bajra).
grains on the ear (not yet threshed).
of an ear of grain, to start to form.
of an ear of grain to become fully formed.

definition: to throw or scoop up with the hands or with the forepaws (dogs, rats). (used of the action of a man digging with his hands e.g. to get water near a stream or scooping out rice being husked from a hole, or of a dog digging for a buried bone).

subwords.sub_definition: to seek for or get by scooping up with the hands or forepaws.
to take out by a scooping action with the hands or paws.

definition: to whistle (also gole).

subwords.sub_definition: to whistle to sleep (e.g. a Ḍur bird which closes the eyes as though dozing when hearing someone whistling).

definition: of many fish, to join together in a school (also jemer-jemer).
the sloping bank of a river; the sloping side of a hill or an embankment.
a type of song sung at the Bah feast.
a snail.

subwords.sub_definition: a shell-carrying snail.

definition: a stork.
the White Stork; a pickaxe pointed at one end only.
in a line; in a row.
to drink water from one's cupped hand or from both hands cupped.
a small scaleless fish about 3-4 in. long.
of water, by coming in superabundance, to cause plants, esp. paddy stalks, to become very thin and weak; pass. of plants, esp. paddy, to become thin and weak due to too much water.
to carry some bundle or somebody by a cloth slung over the shoulder and coming down on one side; a bundle so carried (the form génṭe is more common, ef. kut́raṅ, 'to carry on the back').
of a light wind, to blow; of branches, etc. to shake because of a light wind.

subwords.sub_definition: same as geon of a repeated or continued action.

definition: of rats, mice, grasshoppers, etc. to gnaw, nibble; to cut tilae gangai stalks one by one with a datarom.

subwords.sub_definition: to make wither or fade by nibbling at.
to break a rope by gnawing at it.
to gather together by nibbling or gnawing (e.g. of a porcupine thus collecting tubers to ent).

definition: to wail, mourn loudly, e.g. at the time of a death of a loved one.
to tickle (someone).
a type of Poṭokeć (the form Gẽe is also used).
to tickle; the arm-pit; of a bird or fowl, the part of the body under the wings.

subwords.sub_definition: the arm-pit (also called Hatlaḱ).

definition: to smile (pro-longedly, germoń is rather a fleeting smile).
the Jungle Bush Quail.
a particular herb found in the jungles and not eaten before the Heroḱ feast (not identified, cf. E.M. gering ba, H.149/ 4/1, Β.149/10).
to smile (see geré-mesé).

to rub or scour vigourously, refl. gesan to rub the body vigourously against something e.g. to relieve itching. (implies a stronger rubbing than hirga would imply. This word is more commonly heard in its reflexive form).
a light breeze; of a light breeze, to blow.
to come out in very tiny pustules e.g. heat rash, bumburi; of numerous tiny bubbles, to show in one's urine.
to cut flesh; to play (cut) a fiddle with a bow.

subwords.sub_definition: to cut into flesh causing a wound.

definition: in a line, in a row (e.g. peas in a pod).
to go along the side e.g. of a hill (can be used as a verb form or with the affix -te and a verb of motion).
a dwarf fleshy- leaved plant with flowers reddish-yellow and green, Aloe vera, L. Liliaceae, B.145/3.
to wave, e.g. of high grass or paddy in a breeze, or of a sari waving in a breeze.
of a paste, e.g. mud mortar, to be rather watery; of many small fishes, to descend together through some water course.
to strike with a swinging (not straight) motion of the fist.

subwords.sub_definition: to call a curse on someone by striking oneself with one's fist (see also tapiṅ-saraḱ and tam-saraḱ).
to strike one's breast (refl. form).

definition: a glass (Chombe is also used for this).

subwords.sub_definition: an aluminium bela (as distinct from the more expensive käsa (brass) bela which has a rim (kandom) around the top).
an aluminium plate.

definition: a small dish for serving curry, etc.
a mongoose.

subwords.sub_definition: a plant from which medicine is made for wounds. Esp from its roots and sometimes from its leaves a paste is made which is put onto wounds even on fractured bones.

definition: a wall.
a thing (an alternate form for the more common Jinis).
private parts of the human body (verbal noun of giuḱ).
of the sari of a woman, to be wide and sweeping along the ground (with verb sen, etc.).
of a large falling object (e.g. a man or an animal) to make a loud thud noise when hitting the ground (with verb gur, baṭi, etc.).

subwords.sub_definition: of a large animal (e.g. a bear or elephant) to make a loud thumping noise when running (with verb nir, etc.).

definition: of rain, to fall with big drops making a loud noise (with verb gama).

subwords.sub_definition: same as above of a continued action.

definition: a gimlet (tool for boring holes).
a red stone from which colour can be gotten e.g. for dying clothes sleep (with dum, düm-med, or med dium as object).

subwords.sub_definition: a kind of dove, reddish brown in colour, prob. the Red Turtle Dove.

definition: to shudder, e.g. in horror, fear or disgust; used with laiḱ of the nervous ('sinking') feeling one gets in the stomach e.g. when coming down on a high swing.

subwords.sub_definition: the same of a ued experience.

definition: having a covering of oil, used of oil on any object or oil floating on top of water; sleek and smooth as though with a coating of oil (used thus of the smooth skin or some animalsḱ to have a covering of oil).

subwords.sub_definition: to have a sleek, smooth appearance, e.g. gid-leka neloḱtana, it (e.g. the skin of an animal) has a sleek appearance.
same as gid, gít́ leka.

definition: to lie down; to sleep; a place for sleeping, arrangements for sleeping, as verbal affix in terms such as agom gitić, dili gitić (used in prayers) to perform the action of the primary root before lying down to sleep at night in preparation for a further action, usually a sacrifice, to be performed the next day.

subwords.sub_definition: to lie down to sleep prayers).
to sleep until dawn
bed time (about 9- 10PM).
to sleep.
to fall into a deep sleep, e.g. gitić goć akanać he is in a deep sleep'.
to lie (sleep) still.
about 11- 12P.M.
to watch over some thing by lying down near it.
to lie down unable to rise (stuck' to the bed) e.g. be- cause of extreme weakness.
to lie down with the arms, legs or wings spread out.
to sleep.
to catch up on one's.
to lie down stretching oneself out at full length.
to be perfectly quiet with every one asleep (or as it is when everyone is asleep).
to take rest lying down (refl. form).

definition: sand.

subwords.sub_definition: a desert.
a place where water comes up from sand (used in prayers).
same as M̱araḱ Kaṭa Ut́, q.v.
the supposed invisible sand-insects or the personified sand grains which cut away at the bare feet of one working for long periods in water-soaked fields.

definition: ghee (givu is sometimes used in prayers; in ordinary conversations Gotom is used).
shame, disgrace; shyness; to be ashamed; to be bashful, to be shy (Les. 26).

subwords.sub_definition: to cause one shame by accusing falsely.
shame; shyness.
a matter of shame.

definition: of yoked cattle, to drag a heavy load, one end fastened to the yoke and the other end dragging on the ground.
a cattle shed.

subwords.sub_definition: a spirit who protects the cattle shed; a sacrifice to get his protection for the cattle (in many parts of the Kolhan held on the ote ili feast preceding the mage feast).
a cattle shed.
a cattle-shed full (of cattle).

definition: to repay in meat, usually chicken, one who ploughs one's fields using his own cattle and plough; to repay by such work for meat received.
to beseech, pray (either an animate object marker may be inserted to refer to the person beseeched or are marker may be affixed to the person beseeched).

subwords.sub_definition: a petition song or hymn, a Psalm.
to offer prayers before sleeping at night in anticipation of a sacrifice to be performed the next day.

definition: a jantaṛa (q.v.) rite performed before taking fertilizer (Gurić etc.) from the Dubi to put into the fields (formerly practiced, now going out of use).

to kill; to beat; dead; to extinguish a light (for this ẽeć is the more proper word); refl. goćenn to commit suicide; note the expression goć ket́buać, 'he has killed us', 'we are dead' (said by someone who foresees certain death for himself and his companions).

subwords.sub_definition: to decrease the number by killing or in pass., by dying.
unconscious; to make someone unconscious; pass. to become unconscious, to faint.
to die and leave be hind (e.g. a widow or children).
an inactive ant-hill (also called rõ bunum, compare jid bunum).
to be stretched out stiff in death, e.g. when rigor mortis has set in.
to die stretched out.
to thin out by dying (e.g. the number of paddy stalks in a field).
to die out completely.
to die with shaking convulsions, esp. of chickens.
to escape death; goć pochakanko, 'those who escaped death', 'the survivors.
to die leaving a widow; to widow; pass. to be widowed.
to die with the teeth showing.
to die with the teeth clamped and lips pulled back.
to cause (someone) to have a fit or convulsion; Pass. to have a fit or convulsion.
to kill off a family, pass. of a family, to die off leaving no male descendant.
to kill by draining off water (used esp. of the effect of the sun drying out paddy fields pre venting the grains from forming properly).
straw which has not properly formed due to a lack of water.
still born.
something that kills, something which is lethal.

definition: death (verbal noun of goć, 'to die'); pass. verb to havea death in one's family or village; $ to commit suicide (refl. form of goć, the form goćenn is also used).

subwords.sub_definition: death throes; dying agony.
an omen indicating that death will occur (also called gogoć ere).

When used with a name the word gomke follows the name (as do terms such as munda and manki) e.g. Bodra Gomke, Father Bodra'. The forms gomkin, 'my master', gomkem, 'your master', and gomkete. a ceremony by which a wife newly brought to her husband’s house is initiated into cooking the meal for the family. A sacrifice usually of a chicken is made after which an offering is made to the ancestors in the Adiṅ to get their blessing on the new wife. Until this is done the new wife may not enter the Adiṅ nor touch the Manḍi Chaṭu. After this she cooks her first meal to which all those to whom she must show special respect are invited so that she may recognize them; to initiate a newly brought wife by this ceremony

all those descended from a common ancestor (from people who once ate from the same pot). This is reckoned as far back as people can remember, e.g. 4 or 5 generations. definition: to say; to reflect (N.B. men as distinct from kaji often has this interior meaning, e.g. jibonreko menena, 'they reflect within their spirits'). English indirect discourse can be translated as follows - - gapale hućoḱako men ket́a, 'they said that they would come tomorrow'. (The exact words spoken are used followed by the required form of the verb men, Les. 35, 36). Men is not used when in English we have an indirect object, 'to say to ...'; in that case meta, q.v. would be used. When meaning 'say instead of a full verb form merely the root men is used 1) when quoting replies made by some third person, e.g. Kań hhućoḱać men, 'He says that he will not come' or 2) when emphasizing one's own words, e.g., 'Kań senoḱa'ń men, 'I say that I will not go' (after having already Said it and the hearer did not hear or insisted to the contarary); The passive form menoḱ is used meaning 'to be said', 'to be called something, e.g. nena chikana; menoḱaa, 'what is this called?', but it is also used meaning 'to say or reflect to one's advantage'; men is also used in the same way as menteaḱ or mena instead of mente, 'that' (following direct discourse) when the word for saying is a noun, e.g. Haturen kuiko kako paeṭia men kajido banoḱa, 'The fact is not that village women do not work'

subwords.sub_definition: to tell beforehand (unlike men this can take an -a aspect marker, e.g. men-ayeraḍkoać, ‘He told them beforehand’)

to reply (unlike the simple men form this can take an -a aspect marker, e.g. men-uraaàkoać, ‘he will reply to them’)

same as menteaḱ, (Les. 35)
perhaps (used after verb forms with the -a mood marker dropped, e.g. okoe chi okoe idi ket́ mena, ‘perhaps someone or other took it’)

to be present, exist, be home; with an inan. subject the form menaḱ is used, with animate subj. forms, the forms menaḱńa. etc. are used (see Les. 18 and 36); to have (in certain constructions, Les. 21); used as a participle/adjective as in the examples given here, esu Baba-Biti menaḱ Oaḱ, ‘a house having much wealth’, Koahon mit́hoo ge menaḱć Oaḱ, 'a house in which there is only one son', sangi Hon ko menaḱko Oaḱ, 'a house in which there are many children' (See Les. 18)

subwords.sub_definition: to already be

an adjectival form modifying an animate noun and meaning either 1) being present (after a form ending in -re, ‘in’, e.g. Ote re menaḱtan Nage ko, ‘Nage spirits present in a field’) or 2) ‘having’, ‘possessing’, e.g. Poesa menaḱtan sepeet́ ko, ‘young men having money’. from menaḱtan noun forms are formed, (sg.) menaḱtanić, (dl.) menaḱtankin, (pl.) menaḱtanko, e.g. Ote re menaḱtanić, ‘the one (anim.) on the ground’, bugin Sal Ote ko menaḱtanko, ‘those having good low fields’

1) an adjectival form modifying an inanimate noun with usage the same as given under menaḱtan (which is used with animate nouns), e.g. Baba menaḱ teaḱ Muṭi, ‘a sheaf which has paddy grains on it’; 2) a noun form menaḱteaḱ in the sing. and menaḱ teaḱko in the pl. meaning ‘that which is present or possessed’
to be from earlier times, e.g. of some custom which has come down

definition: to have a foot or both feet turned in e.g. due to some defect from birth; of the horns of cattle, to curve off in a different direction than that with which they come out of the head

used something like mente in indirect discourse but with the connotation of making oneself to be, supposing or presuming oneself to be, etc. e.g. maraṅań meneet́ sama hoo loḱ te bugite kać jagara, ‘Supposing himself to be important he does not converse nicely with an ordinary man’; meneet́ is also used after an animate noun or pronoun and before a verb to indicate that the subject did well to have done that action, e.g. apudo kać kaji ket́a, hon meneet́ uduṕ ket́a, “The father did not tell it, happily the child revealed it’

to say; to reflect (N.B. men as distinct from kaji often has this interior meaning, e.g. Jibon rekô menena, ‘they reflect within their spirits’). English indirect discourse can be translated as follows - - gapale hućoḱako men ket́a, ‘they said that they would come tomorrow’. (The exact words spoken are used followed by the required form of the verb men, Les. 35,36). Men is not used when in English we have an indirect object, ‘to say to ...’; in that case meta, q.v. would be used. When meaning ‘say instead of a full verb form merely the root men is used 1) when quoting replies made by some third person, e.g. Kań hhućoḱać men, ‘He says that he will not come’ or 2) when emphasizing one’s own words, e.g., Kań senoḱań men, ‘I say that I will not go’ (after having already Said it and the hearer did not hear or insisted to the contarary); The passive form menoḱ is used meaning ‘to be said', 'to be called something, e.g. nena chikana; menoḱa, ‘what is this called?', but it is also used meaning 'to say or reflect to one’s advantage’; men is also used in the same way as menteaḱ or mena instead of mente, ‘that’ (following direct discourse) when the word for saying is a noun, e.g. Haturen Kui ko kako paeṭia men kajido banoḱa, ‘The fact is not that village women do not work’

definition: poison given through witchcraft, usually to enemy in a rice meal or in rice beer. It is believed that if the original poison (najom was from a chicken, that a chicken-like growth will develop in the stomach of the man and cause his death, and that if the poison is from a goat, a goat-like growth will develop, etc. Then it is believed that after the man has died, if his body is cremated, this growth will not burn. Someone who wants to poison an enemy in this way will try to get some of this unburned growth from the cremated body of a man so poisoned. It is believed that it is portions of such growths removed from dead bodies that are used for najom

The reciprocal infix (the reciprocal of any verb can be formed by infixing the reciprocal marker -p- after the first vowel of a verb root and then repeating that vowel after the -p-. If this first vowel is long, it retains its long quality only after the -p- infix (Les. 23); a -p- infix is also used in a few superlatives, e.g. máparaṅ, hupuḍiṅ, jipiliṅ; also a -p- infix is used in a few terms implying relationship, e.g. eperate, 'his wife', hopon, sepēt́ (prob. from seet́ as in hon sēt́)

definition: soul. Every man has a Jiv and a Rva. The Jiv is the principle of life. When this goes a man dies. The Rva of a man does not die. While a man is still alive his Rva can leave his body and move around, e.g. when he is dreaming or at time of near death or sickness (see Rva kea-uraa). When a man dies his Rva leaves the body and later is called into the adiṅ of his family in the kea-ader ceremony.

subwords.sub_definition: soul-killing, mortal(sin)

to call back a man's Rva which has left his body prior to death. Used in two cases - - 1) for a man who is near death or apparently dead, sometimes a Deõa will make efforts to call back into his body his Rva which perhaps is hiding in some nearby deep water, etc. 2) for a man who has physically recovered from sickness but is still weak and restless (Jiv ka sukuića) or mentally disturbed, divination or sacrifices are performed to recall his Rva, which is believed to still be roaming apart from the body, back into the body

definition: the throat (N.B. distinct from Uṭúṭuaḱ the adam's apple)
curry; to use as curry.

a vegetable creeper, from its fruit a reddish juice can be extracted with which children sometimes in jest paint their toe nails, Basella rubra, L., Chenopodiaceae, B. 109/1, H.109/7/1 (this is also called maraṅ uṭu, jomè uṭu, to distinguish it from chuṭu lutur uṭu, q.v.).

covered with dense undergrowth so that it is difficult to pass through (also aṭa-puṭu).
see utkut́.
of a small bug, to walk under e.g. a paper causing that to quiver; of a person entirely covered e.g. with a blanket, to move slightly making the covering quiver

subwords.sub_definition: same as uṭul.

definition: a very large round shaped rock (also huṭub, cf. Sereṅ of a large flat rock).
to butt (also roḱ); to push with the head

subwords.sub_definition: to overturn by butting.

to push out of the way with the head (e.g. a man pushing clothes aside); of a pig, to push into the earth with its snout.
to kill by butting..
to make collapse by butting with the head.
